content:
Name "loop" is overloaded in mathlib. It's used to refer to either a single edge uu or a walk from u to u. We should resolve this conflict.

These are mentions of "loop" as a walk from u to u I could found:

  • SimpleGraph.Walk.three_le_chromaticNumber_of_odd_loop
  • SimpleGraph.two_colorable_iff_forall_loop_even
  • SimpleGraph.Walk.rotate
  • SimpleGraph.Path.loop_eq
  • SimpleGraph.Path.notMem_edges_of_loop

These are mentions of "loop" as a single edge uu I could found:

  • SimpleGraph.loopless
  • Graph.IsLoopAt and assiociated theorems
  • Graph.IsNonloopAt and associated theorems
  • Graph.loopSet and associated theorems
  • I don't know anything about matroids, but in the description of Matroid.Loop it says "for graphic matroids, they correspond to edges incident with just one vertex (aka 'loops')", so I guess this whole module too.

To resolve this conflict we should change the name of one or the other (or both).
Another name for a walk from u to u could be "closed walk".
Another name for an edge uu could be "self-loop".

What do you think?

Seems like the name "loop" is already used in definitions to refer to edge uu, so renaming those few theorems that use this name to refer to a walk from u to u is probably the best course of action here. Any other propositions then "closed walk"?
How about "cycle" for the walk from u to u? Ah, but a closed walk should allow to visit u in between too and have other repeats, I see now. Thanks MrQubo.
We already have "cycle" and it means something more. It's like walk vs path. SimpleGraph.Walk.IsCycle
I agree the use of loop to refer to a closed walk is potentially confusing, while loopless seems pretty standard so this sounds like a sensible change.

Both natural numbers and integers can be even, does that mean that we should have different words for them? The situation seems similar to me, both edges and walks can be loops. They're compatible too, since an edge is a loop if and only if the corresponding single-edge walk is a loop.

Having "closed walk" makes some sense, and it would be ok if that were the terminology, but we should think about whether we should use different words for a concept that works in multiple types in a compatible way.

You mention the name is overloaded. Have you found it to be confusing?

Terminology is like notation, and we accept overloaded notation when the concept is similar among the different usages.
You're right. I think there could be some potential for confusion, but maybe there isn't. We can decide once we get more theorems about "loops".
